newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-Australian/US spread back in the 100 bp area.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-Australian/US spread back in the 100 bp area.

text.p: Australian bonds continued to drag their heels against U.S. Treasuries as the local market is finding difficulty in extending its rally without a widely expected easing in official interest rates.

The Australian/U.S. 10-year bond yield spread was back hugging 100 basis points after underperforming a massive rally in the U.S. on Tuesday, to stand well above last week's low 80s, which immediately followed a benign quarter wages report.

The market took a surprise A$1.69 billion widening in Australia's current account deficit for September in its stride as one month's figures were not seen having any impact on a possible easing in monetary policy.
Meanwhile, U.S. bonds raced ahead following a more moderate than expected September quarter employment costs index and a fall in consumer confidence.
The U.S. faces third quarter GDP later today.
Canadian debt got sucked into the U.S. rally, ending several days of underperformance against local bonds, while New Zealand bonds succumbed to a fairly subdued session.
The local yield flattened as the long end benefitted more from the U.S. rally, while some tired long positions were off-loaded in the short end in the absence of a move from the Reserve Bank.
